user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of try_match_header:
```c
static int
try_match_header (const char *prefix,
                  size_t prefix_len,
                  char *line,
                  char **suffix)
{
  if (NULL != *suffix)
    return MHD_NO;
  while (0 != *line)
  {
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_ (prefix,
                                   line,
                                   prefix_len))
    {
      *suffix = strdup (&line[prefix_len]);
      return MHD_YES;
    }
    ++line;
  }
  return MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function try_match_header:
int
MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_ (const char *const str1,
                           const char *const str2,
                           size_t maxlen)
{
  size_t i;

  for (i = 0; i < maxlen; ++i)
  {
    const char c1 = str1[i];
    const char c2 = str2[i];
    if (0 == c2)
      return 0 == c1;
    if (charsequalcaseless (c1, c2))
      continue;
    else
      return 0;
  }
  return ! 0;
}
...
_MHD_static_inline bool
charsequalcaseless (const char c1, const char c2)
{
  return ( (c1 == c2) ||
           (isasciiupper (c1) ?
            ((c1 - 'A' + 'a') == c2) :
            ((c1 == (c2 - 'A' + 'a')) && isasciiupper (c2))) );
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: All other code constructs in the provided fragments use standard C syntax and standard types (e.g. static, int, const, size_t, pointers, loops, returns, ternary operator). There are no explicit compiler-specific keywords or built-ins visible (such as __attribute__, __builtin_*, __asm__, typeof, __declspec, __inline__ with compiler-specific spelling, or other documented compiler extensions). The identifiers and expressions not listed above therefore do not by themselves indicate use of language extensions. The items reported are suspicious because: 1) _MHD_static_inline is a macro whose definition may map to a compiler-specific inline/attribute construct and thus could be a language/implementation extension; 2) strdup is not part of ISO C (it is commonly a POSIX/implementation extension) and may indicate use of nonstandard library functions; 3) isasciiupper (and by similarity any isascii* family) is not part of ISO C and may be an implementation-specific function or macro. Those reported fragments should be investigated further (expand the macro definitions and check library availability/documentation) to determine whether they rely on language/compiler extensions. No other fragments in the provided code appear to use compiler language extensions.
